clusters.title: Israel says hostages will be freed from Gaza 'in a few hours' as ceasefire holds
clusters.neutral_headline: Israel Awaits Hostage Release, Trump to Meet Families

items.title: Israel says hostages will be freed from Gaza 'in a few hours' as ceasefire holds
items.standfirst: All living hostages held in the Gaza Strip will be released early Monday morning as part of a breakthrough ceasefire deal with Hamas, Israel said on Sunday, as Palestinians awaited the release of hundreds of prisoners held in Israel. US President Donald Trump, who will arrive Monday morning in Israel, will meet with families of the hostages and speak at the Knesset, Israel’s parliament.
items.content: All living hostages held in the Gaza Strip will be released early Monday morning as part of a breakthrough ceasefire deal with Hamas, Israel said on Sunday, as Palestinians awaited the release of hundreds of prisoners held in Israel. US President Donald Trump, who will arrive Monday morning in Israel, will meet with families of the hostages and speak at the Knesset, Israel’s parliament.

items.title: Gaza ceasefire live: Trump to meet with Israeli hostages after their release by Hamas on Monday, says Vance
items.standfirst: US vice-president JD Vance says release could happen ‘any moment’ and that ‘we are on cusp of a sustainable Middle East peace’Israeli prime minister, Benjamin Netanyahu, has said that Israel is ready for the “immediate” reception of all Gaza hostages.“Israel is prepared and ready to immediately receive all of our hostages,” he said in a statement after a meeting with the coordinator for the hostage coordinator Gal Hirsch. Continue reading...

items.title: Israel expects all 20 living hostages to be freed from Gaza on Monday morning
items.standfirst: Government says it is also preparing for release of 2,000 Palestinian detainees in crucial next phase of ceasefire dealCeasefire live: aid trucks enter Gaza as Netanyahu says Israel is ready for ‘immediate’ release of hostagesThe Israeli government says it expects all living hostages held in Gaza to be released on Monday morning and that it is preparing for the release of about 2,000 Palestinian detainees, the crucial next phase of the ceasefire deal that could end the two-year war in Gaza.“We are expecting all 20 of our living hostages to be released together at one time to the Red Cross and transported among six to eight vehicles,” said the Israeli government spokesperson Shosh Bedrosian. Continue reading...
items.content: Government says it is also preparing for release of 2,000 Palestinian detainees in crucial next phase of ceasefire dealCeasefire live: aid trucks enter Gaza as Netanyahu says Israel is ready for ‘immediate’ release of hostagesThe Israeli government says it expects all living hostages held in Gaza to be released on Monday morning and that it is preparing for the release of about 2,000 Palestinian detainees, the crucial next phase of the ceasefire deal that could end the two-year war in Gaza.“We are expecting all 20 of our living hostages to be released together at one time to the Red Cross and transported among six to eight vehicles,” said the Israeli government spokesperson Shosh Bedrosian. Continue reading...

items.title: Gaza live: Palestinian prisoners will be freed after all Gaza hostages returned to Israel
items.standfirst: Israel will begin releasing Palestinian prisoners once it has confirmation that all hostages held in Gaza have arrived in the country, a spokeswoman for the prime minister said Sunday. An Israeli government spokesperson confirmed on Sunday that the release of hostages held in Gaza will begin early Monday morning. All 20 living hostages are expected to be released together at one time, followed by the bodies of 28 deceased. Follow our liveblog for the latest updates.
items.content: Israel will begin releasing Palestinian prisoners once it has confirmation that all hostages held in Gaza have arrived in the country, a spokeswoman for the prime minister said Sunday. An Israeli government spokesperson confirmed on Sunday that the release of hostages held in Gaza will begin early Monday morning. All 20 living hostages are expected to be released together at one time, followed by the bodies of 28 deceased. Follow our liveblog for the latest updates.

items.title: Gaza ceasefire holds but key issues remain unresolved ahead of peace summit
items.standfirst: Hamas will begin releasing Israeli hostages held in Gaza on Monday morning as part of the first phase of a peace deal pushed by US President Donald Trump that will also see the release of nearly 2,000 Palestinian prisoners. But many issues remain unresolved as Trump and his Egyptian counterpart Abdel Fattah al-Sisi prepare to chair a summit of more than 20 countries in the Red Sea resort of Sharm el-Sheikh.
items.content: Hamas will begin releasing Israeli hostages held in Gaza on Monday morning as part of the first phase of a peace deal pushed by US President Donald Trump that will also see the release of nearly 2,000 Palestinian prisoners. But many issues remain unresolved as Trump and his Egyptian counterpart Abdel Fattah al-Sisi prepare to chair a summit of more than 20 countries in the Red Sea resort of Sharm el-Sheikh.

items.title: Deadly Afghanistan-Pakistan clashes could ignite wider conflict
items.standfirst: Deadly clashes erupted along Afghanistan’s border with Pakistan, marking a new low in the countries’ ties since the Taliban retook power in 2021. The violence killed dozens of Pakistani soldiers and Taliban fighters and comes days after Islamabad bombed an Afghan market close to the border,…
items.content: Deadly clashes erupted along Afghanistan’s border with Pakistan, marking a new low in the countries’ ties since the Taliban retook power in 2021. The violence killed dozens of Pakistani soldiers and Taliban fighters and comes days after Islamabad bombed an Afghan market close to the border,…

items.title: Border clashes between Afghanistan and Pakistan leave dozens dead
items.standfirst: Afghanistan and Pakistan said on Sunday they killed dozens of each other's troops during a night of heavy border clashes between the two countries. Afghanistan's Taliban forces launched attacks on Pakistani troops along their shared border late on Saturday, in what it called "retaliation for air strikes carried out by the Pakistani army on Kabul" on Thursday.
items.content: Afghanistan and Pakistan said on Sunday they killed dozens of each other's troops during a night of heavy border clashes between the two countries. Afghanistan's Taliban forces launched attacks on Pakistani troops along their shared border late on Saturday, in what it called "retaliation for air strikes carried out by the Pakistani army on Kabul" on Thursday.

items.content: Deadly clashes erupted overnight between the Taliban and Pakistani forces across the Afghanistan border.

items.title: Dozens killed in Pakistan-Afghanistan border clashes
items.standfirst: Dozens of fighters were killed in overnight border clashes between Pakistan and Afghanistan, both sides said on Sunday, in the most serious fighting between the neighbours since the Taliban came to power in Kabul. FRANCE 24's Shahzaib Wahlah reports from Islamabad.
items.content: Dozens of fighters were killed in overnight border clashes between Pakistan and Afghanistan, both sides said on Sunday, in the most serious fighting between the neighbours since the Taliban came to power in Kabul. FRANCE 24's Shahzaib Wahlah reports from Islamabad.

items.title: Heavy clashes erupt along Pakistan-Afghanistan border
items.standfirst: Escalation comes after Pakistani airstrike in Kabul, with Taliban launching reprisals against military postsIntense clashes erupted along the Pakistan-Afghanistan border on Saturday night, after an attack by the Afghan Taliban on Pakistani military posts led to a heavy exchange of fire and reportedly left dozens of soldiers dead.According to officials, Afghan troops opened fire on Pakistani army posts along the north-western border with Pakistan on Saturday night and seized several of the posts. The attacks came after the Taliban regime in Afghanistan accused Pakistan of carrying out airstrikes on Afghan territory, including in the capital, Kabul, earlier this week. Continue reading...
items.content: Escalation comes after Pakistani airstrike in Kabul, with Taliban launching reprisals against military postsIntense clashes erupted along the Pakistan-Afghanistan border on Saturday night, after an attack by the Afghan Taliban on Pakistani military posts led to a heavy exchange of fire and reportedly left dozens of soldiers dead.According to officials, Afghan troops opened fire on Pakistani army posts along the north-western border with Pakistan on Saturday night and seized several of the posts. The attacks came after the Taliban regime in Afghanistan accused Pakistan of carrying out airstrikes on Afghan territory, including in the capital, Kabul, earlier this week. Continue reading...

items.title: Pakistan closes border with Afghanistan after dozens killed in overnight clashes
items.standfirst: Pakistan closed all border crossings with Afghanistan on Sunday after deadly overnight clashes in which both sides claimed to have killed dozens of troops. Islamabad regularly accuses the Taliban administration in Kabul of harbouring militants who attack Pakistan, a charge Afghan officials deny.

items.content: Soldiers join mass antigovernment protests, urging no violence, as unrest over shortages and political divisions grows.

items.title: Madagascar’s president says illegal power grab by military is under way
items.standfirst: Soldiers from elite Capsat unit have announced they are taking over after weeks of youth-led protestsMadagascar’s president said an “attempt to seize power illegally and by force” was under way, as an elite military unit that joined protesters on the streets on Saturday announced it was taking over the army.The Capsat unit’s intervention comes after weeks of youth-led protests, which started on 25 September against water and electricity shortages and expanded to calling for the resignation of the president, Andry Rajoelina, an end to corruption and radical overhaul of the political system. Continue reading...
items.content: Soldiers from elite Capsat unit have announced they are taking over after weeks of youth-led protestsMadagascar’s president said an “attempt to seize power illegally and by force” was under way, as an elite military unit that joined protesters on the streets on Saturday announced it was taking over the army.The Capsat unit’s intervention comes after weeks of youth-led protests, which started on 25 September against water and electricity shortages and expanded to calling for the resignation of the president, Andry Rajoelina, an end to corruption and radical overhaul of the political system. items.content: Elite troops join youth-led protests over utilities that have swelled into gravest threat for President Andry Rajoelina.

items.title: Madagascar leader says power grab under way as army unit claims control of military
items.standfirst: Madagascar's President Andry Rajoelina said in a statement on Sunday that "an attempt to seize power illegally and by force" was underway in the Indian Ocean island state, a day after some soldiers joined a vast protest movement that started last month. The mutinied army unit announced it was taking control of all military forces in the country.
items.content: Madagascar's President Andry Rajoelina said in a statement on Sunday that "an attempt to seize power illegally and by force" was underway in the Indian Ocean island state, a day after some soldiers joined a vast protest movement that started last month. The mutinied army unit announced it was taking control of all military forces in the country.

items.title: Soldiers from elite Capsat unit join protests against Madagascar’s president
items.standfirst: Demonstrators march alongside regiment, who earlier in the day said they would not fire on the crowdsMadagascar’s prime minister called for calm after an elite group of soldiers joined thousands of protesters against the country’s president on the streets of the capital on Saturday afternoon.Protesters marched alongside soldiers from the Capsat unit, who drove armoured vehicles, some waving Madagascar flags, from their base in Soanierana in the south of Antananarivo. Continue reading...
items.content: Demonstrators march alongside regiment, who earlier in the day said they would not fire on the crowdsMadagascar’s prime minister called for calm after an elite group of soldiers joined thousands of protesters against the country’s president on the streets of the capital on Saturday afternoon.Protesters marched alongside soldiers from the Capsat unit, who drove armoured vehicles, some waving Madagascar flags, from their base in Soanierana in the south of Antananarivo. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Madagascar's president said an attempt to seize power was underway.
An elite military unit announced it was taking over the army.
Soldiers from the Capsat unit joined youth-led anti-government protests.
Protests began over water and electricity shortages and expanded.
The protests now call for the president's resignation and reform.

clusters.title: Cameroon holds presidential elections with incumbent Biya poised for 8th term
clusters.neutral_headline: Cameroon Holds Presidential Elections

items.title: Cameroon holds presidential elections with incumbent Biya poised for 8th term
items.standfirst: Voters cast their ballots Sunday in Cameroon's presidential elections, which 92-year-old Paul Biya, the world's oldest serving head of state, is expected to win, extending his already 43-year grip on power. Biya faces 11 opponents, including former employment minister Issa Tchiroma Bakary, 79, who has generated unexpected enthusiasm among voters in the central African nation, where half the population is under 20. FRANCE 24's Indira Eteng reports from Yaoundé.
items.content: Voters cast their ballots Sunday in Cameroon's presidential elections, which 92-year-old Paul Biya, the world's oldest serving head of state, is expected to win, extending his already 43-year grip on power. Biya faces 11 opponents, including former employment minister Issa Tchiroma Bakary, 79, who has generated unexpected enthusiasm among voters in the central African nation, where half the population is under 20. FRANCE 24's Indira Eteng reports from Yaoundé.

items.title: Cameroon votes in presidential election as Paul Biya, 92, seeks eighth term

items.content: Biya, the world’s oldest serving head of state, is likely to extend his 43 years in power in Central African nation.

items.title: Voting closes in Cameroon presidential election where world's oldest leader Biya seeks eighth term
items.standfirst: Polls closed in Cameroon on Sunday in an election that could see Africa’s oldest leader Paul Biya, aged 92, extend his 43-year rule by another 7 years. Biya faces nine opposition candidates, including some former allies and appointees.
items.content: Polls closed in Cameroon on Sunday in an election that could see Africa’s oldest leader Paul Biya, aged 92, extend his 43-year rule by another 7 years. Biya faces nine opposition candidates, including some former allies and appointees.

items.title: Cameroon’s 92-year-old president set for another term as country goes to polls
items.standfirst: Paul Biya, in power since 1982, has brushed off calls to retire but is rarely seen in publicCameroon goes to the polls on Sunday for a presidential election with Paul Biya, already the world’s oldest head of state at the age of 92, the favourite to win an eighth term in power in the central African country.A fractured opposition of 11 candidates is standing against Biya, who, despite his advanced age and declining health, has dismissed calls for him to retire. Continue reading...
items.content: Paul Biya, in power since 1982, has brushed off calls to retire but is rarely seen in publicCameroon goes to the polls on Sunday for a presidential election with Paul Biya, already the world’s oldest head of state at the age of 92, the favourite to win an eighth term in power in the central African country.A fractured opposition of 11 candidates is standing against Biya, who, despite his advanced age and declining health, has dismissed calls for him to retire. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Cameroon held presidential elections on Sunday, with Paul Biya seeking an eighth term.
Paul Biya, 92, is the world's oldest serving head of state.
Biya has been in power for 43 years and faces 11 opponents.
Voting closed in the election, with Biya expected to win.
The opposition includes former allies and appointees of Biya.

items.title: Watch: Tennessee town comes together to confront tragedy
items.standfirst: Authorities have confirmed that 16 people were killed when an explosives plant in rural Tennessee exploded on Friday morning.
items.content: Authorities have confirmed that 16 people were killed when an explosives plant in rural Tennessee exploded on Friday morning.

items.title: 16 people died in a blast at a Tennessee explosives factory early Friday, sheriff says
items.standfirst: A blast in rural Tennessee that leveled an explosives plant and was felt for miles around killed 16 people and left no survivors, authorities said.
items.content: A blast in rural Tennessee that leveled an explosives plant and was felt for miles around killed 16 people and left no survivors, authorities said.(Image credit: Obed Lamy)

items.title: Sheriff says Tennessee explosives factory blast left no survivors
items.standfirst: A blast on Friday at the rural Tennessee Accurate Energetic Systems plant, which supplies and researches explosives for the military, left no survivors, authorities said, adding that the 16 people inside the building are presumed to be deceased.
items.content: A blast on Friday at the rural Tennessee Accurate Energetic Systems plant, which supplies and researches explosives for the military, left no survivors, authorities said, adding that the 16 people inside the building are presumed to be deceased.

ai_summary: A blast at a Tennessee explosives factory killed sixteen people.
Authorities confirmed there were no survivors from the explosion.
The blast occurred at the Accurate Energetic Systems plant.
The plant supplies and researches explosives for the military.
The explosion was felt for miles around the rural Tennessee area.

items.title: 10/12: Face the Nation with Margaret Brennan
items.standfirst: This week on "Face the Nation with Margaret Brennan," Vice President JD Vance joins as President Trump heads to the Middle East amid the critical moment in the Israel-Hamas peace deal and at home, as the ongoing government shutdown drags on. Plus. Egyptian foreign minister Badr Abdelatty joins.

Plus. Egyptian foreign minister Badr Abdelatty joins.

items.title: Face the Nation: Murphy, Himes
items.standfirst: Missed the second half of the show? Democratic Sen. Chris Murphy of Connecticut and Democratic Rep. Jim Himes of Connecticut join.
items.content: Missed the second half of the show? Democratic Sen. Chris Murphy of Connecticut and Democratic Rep. Jim Himes of Connecticut join.

items.title: Rep. Jim Himes says "Congress is being told nothing" about U.S. strikes on Venezuelan vessels
items.standfirst: Rep. Jim Himes of Connecticut, who is the top Democrat on the House Intelligence Committee, told "Face the Nation with Margaret Brennan" that "Congress is being told nothing" about the Trump administration's strikes on Venezuelan vessels that are allegedly being used to carry drugs. "Based on what I know now" and the White House's memo on the strikes, "these are illegal killings," Himes added.
items.content: Rep. Jim Himes of Connecticut, who is the top Democrat on the House Intelligence Committee, told "Face the Nation with Margaret Brennan" that "Congress is being told nothing" about the Trump administration's strikes on Venezuelan vessels that are allegedly being used to carry drugs. "Based on what I know now" and the White House's memo on the strikes, "these are illegal killings," Himes added.

items.title: Sen. Chris Murphy says "only way" to end shutdown is "to have two parties" negotiating
items.standfirst: Sen. Chris Murphy, Democrat of Connecticut, told "Face the Nation with Margaret Brennan" that as Republicans have accused Democrats of refusing to come to the table on the shutdown, "Republicans are boycotting negotiations" with the House on recess. "The only way you can solve a shutdown is to have two parties that are in Washington negotiating," he said.
items.content: Sen. Chris Murphy, Democrat of Connecticut, told "Face the Nation with Margaret Brennan" that as Republicans have accused Democrats of refusing to come to the table on the shutdown, "Republicans are boycotting negotiations" with the House on recess. "The only way you can solve a shutdown is to have two parties that are in Washington negotiating," he said.

items.title: Egypt's foreign minister is "confident" first phase of Gaza peace plan will be implemented
items.standfirst: Egyptian Foreign Minister Badr Abdelatty told "Face the Nation with Margaret Brennan" that he is "confident the first phase of the Trump peace plan will be implemented," adding that Egypt is in "full contact with the Palestinians, with Hamas, because it's all about, of course, releasing the hostages and for Israel, releasing some of the Palestinian detainees."
items.content: Egyptian Foreign Minister Badr Abdelatty told "Face the Nation with Margaret Brennan" that he is "confident the first phase of the Trump peace plan will be implemented," adding that Egypt is in "full contact with the Palestinians, with Hamas, because it's all about, of course, releasing the hostages and for Israel, releasing some of the Palestinian detainees."

Plus. Egyptian foreign minister Badr Abdelatty joins.
items.content: This week on "Face the Nation with Margaret Brennan," Vice President JD Vance joins as President Trump heads to the Middle East amid the critical moment in the Israel-Hamas peace deal and at home, as the ongoing government shutdown drags on. ai_summary: Vice President JD Vance will appear on "Face the Nation with Margaret Brennan."
President Trump will be in the Middle East amid the Israel-Hamas peace deal.
The ongoing government shutdown is also a topic of discussion.
Interviews with Badr Abdelatty, Jim Himes, and Chris Murphy will be aired.
The show will feature transcripts of interviews from October 12, 2025.

items.title: Trump ‘looking at all options’ amid threats to invoke Insurrection Act, Vance says
items.standfirst: Vice-president calls crime ‘out of control’ in US cities as Trump faces legal battles for use of federal forcesThe White House is talking about invoking the Insurrection Act that would allow the deployment of military troops on US soil to quell domestic unrest amid legal challenges over the moves, JD Vance confirmed on Sunday.Vance was asked on NBC News’s Meet the Press whether Donald Trump was seriously considering invoking the emergency power to deploy national guard forces and even the US military in domestic settings. items.title: New Jersey declares state of emergency as nor’easter moves up East Coast
items.standfirst: Heavy rain also was forecast for southeast New England, the New York City area, and some has fallen in coastal sections of South Carolina.
items.content: Heavy rain also was forecast for southeast New England, the New York City area, and some has fallen in coastal sections of South Carolina.

items.title: New Jersey declares state of emergency as nor’easter approaches
items.standfirst: Airports post delays and cancellations in advance of anticipated coastal flooding and strong windsA nor’easter churned its way up the east coast on Sunday, with New Jersey declaring a state of emergency and some airports posting delays and cancellations in advance of anticipated coastal flooding and strong winds, as another storm system struck farther south with heavy rain and flooding.“The greatest effects are going to be the coastal flooding potential, especially for areas from north-eastern North Carolina northward to much of the New Jersey coast,” said meteorologist Bob Oravec with the National Weather Service in College Park, Maryland. Continue reading...
items.content: Airports post delays and cancellations in advance of anticipated coastal flooding and strong windsA nor’easter churned its way up the east coast on Sunday, with New Jersey declaring a state of emergency and some airports posting delays and cancellations in advance of anticipated coastal flooding and strong winds, as another storm system struck farther south with heavy rain and flooding.“The greatest effects are going to be the coastal flooding potential, especially for areas from north-eastern North Carolina northward to much of the New Jersey coast,” said meteorologist Bob Oravec with the National Weather Service in College Park, Maryland. Continue reading...

ai_summary: New Jersey declared a state of emergency due to a nor'easter.
Airports are experiencing delays and cancellations.
Coastal flooding and strong winds are anticipated.
Another storm system is bringing heavy rain farther south.
The greatest effects will be coastal flooding.

The plans are due to expected tax increases in the budget.
Up to 1,500 jobs could be affected by the closures.
Evoke acquired William Hill in a £2bn takeover in 2022.
The budget is expected to be announced on November 26th.

items.title: UK small businesses and charities say nuclear levy could add thousands to bills
items.standfirst: Charge from next month expected to have disproportionate impact after energy-intensive industries given exemptionBritish charities and small businesses have warned that a new levy on energy bills, intended to support the government’s nuclear power ambitions, could raise their costs by thousands of pounds a year.The extra charge could mean a significant cost hike for charities and small businesses with high energy use, meaning community services may be cut and economic growth curtailed, according to trade groups. Continue reading...
items.content: Charge from next month expected to have disproportionate impact after energy-intensive industries given exemptionBritish charities and small businesses have warned that a new levy on energy bills, intended to support the government’s nuclear power ambitions, could raise their costs by thousands of pounds a year.The extra charge could mean a significant cost hike for charities and small businesses with high energy use, meaning community services may be cut and economic growth curtailed, according to trade groups. Continue reading...

ai_summary: UK small businesses and charities warn of a nuclear levy.
The levy could add thousands to energy bills.
Energy-intensive industries have been given an exemption.
The extra charge could hike costs for charities and businesses.
Community services may be cut due to the levy.

This action is a retaliatory measure by the West African state of Mali.

items.title: Jonathan Powell had no role in dropping of China spy case, senior minister says
items.standfirst: Bridget Phillipson says national security adviser was not involved in discussions before CPS abandoned its prosecutionThe government’s national security adviser had no involvement in the prosecution being dropped against two British men accused of spying for China, a senior cabinet minister has said.Jonathan Powell had no connection to discussions about the “substance or the evidence” of the case, Bridget Phillipson said on Sunday, adding that Keir Starmer had full confidence in him. Continue reading...
items.content: Bridget Phillipson says national security adviser was not involved in discussions before CPS abandoned its prosecutionThe government’s national security adviser had no involvement in the prosecution being dropped against two British men accused of spying for China, a senior cabinet minister has said.Jonathan Powell had no connection to discussions about the “substance or the evidence” of the case, Bridget Phillipson said on Sunday, adding that Keir Starmer had full confidence in him. Continue reading...

items.title: Minister says Starmer security adviser had no role in China spy case evidence
items.standfirst: The Conservatives suggest Jonathan Powell's role led to the collapse of the prosecutions against two men.
items.content: The Conservatives suggest Jonathan Powell's role led to the collapse of the prosecutions against two men.

ai_summary: A senior minister stated Jonathan Powell had no involvement in the China spy case.
The minister said Powell was not involved in discussions about the case's evidence.
The Conservatives suggested Powell's role led to the collapse of prosecutions.
Keir Starmer has full confidence in Jonathan Powell, according to the minister.

items.title: Qantas says customer data released by cyber criminals months after cyber breach
Qantas Says Stolen Customer Data Posted Online After Cyberattack
items.standfirst: Qantas Airways Ltd. said customer data stolen during a cyber incident in July has been released online, and that it’s working with security experts and Australian authorities to determine the extent of the exposure.
items.content: Qantas Airways Ltd. said customer data stolen during a cyber incident in July has been released online, and that it’s working with security experts and Australian authorities to determine the extent of the exposure.

clusters.title: Oscar-winner actress Diane Keaton dies aged 79
clusters.neutral_headline: Diane Keaton, Oscar-Winning Actress, Dies at 79

items.title: Oscar-winner actress Diane Keaton dies aged 79
items.standfirst: Diane Keaton, the Oscar-winning star of “Annie Hall,” “The Godfather” films and “Father of the Bride,” whose quirky, vibrant manner and depth made her one of the most singular actors of a generation, has died. She was 79.People Magazine reported Saturday that she died in California with loved ones, citing a family spokesperson.
items.content: Diane Keaton, the Oscar-winning star of “Annie Hall,” “The Godfather” films and “Father of the Bride,” whose quirky, vibrant manner and depth made her one of the most singular actors of a generation, has died. She was 79.People Magazine reported Saturday that she died in California with loved ones, citing a family spokesperson.

items.title: Hollywood's quirky leading lady, Diane Keaton, dies aged 79
items.standfirst: Diane Keaton, who remained one of Hollywood's quirkiest and most beloved actors decades after her Academy Award-winning performance in the movie Annie Hall, has died aged 79.
items.content: Diane Keaton, who remained one of Hollywood's quirkiest and most beloved actors decades after her Academy Award-winning performance in the movie Annie Hall, has died aged 79.(Image credit: Chris Pizzello)

items.title: Diane Keaton, Oscar-winning star of 'Annie Hall' and 'The Godfather,' dies at 79
items.standfirst: The actor, known for her quirky, vibrant manner and depth was 79. Across her decades-long career, she worked with prominent filmmakers including Francis Ford Coppola, Woody Allen and Nancy Meyers.
items.content: The actor, known for her quirky, vibrant manner and depth was 79. Across her decades-long career, she worked with prominent filmmakers including Francis Ford Coppola, Woody Allen and Nancy Meyers.(Image credit: Chris Pizzello/Invision)

items.title: Academy Award-winning actress Diane Keaton dies at 79
items.standfirst: US actress Diane Keaton, known for her Oscar-winning performance in 1977's "Annie Hall" and her role in "The Godfather" films, has died at age 79, People magazine reported Saturday.
items.content: US actress Diane Keaton, known for her Oscar-winning performance in 1977's "Annie Hall" and her role in "The Godfather" films, has died at age 79, People magazine reported Saturday.

ai_summary: Diane Keaton, known for "Annie Hall" and "The Godfather," died at age 79.
She was an Oscar-winning actress with a quirky and vibrant manner.
Keaton worked with prominent filmmakers like Woody Allen and Francis Ford Coppola.
People magazine reported her death in California with family present.

items.content: Named the Hwasong-20, its size suggests that it could carry multiple nuclear warheads.
